messages.content:
Objective: Write code for a large system design task.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.
Only use the functions you have been provided with.
Only use the `write_files` to output code.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.
You always write out the whole file contents. You always indent code with tabs.
Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
When writing a test, make the filename start with the prefix 'test_'.

Provide the minimal code necessary to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persist between steps or write operations.
                               
If a test is failing the error could be the code, or the test is incorrect, so feel free to overwrite and change the tests when they are incorrect, to make all tests pass.

Use the functions provided. When calling functions only provide a RFC8259 compliant JSON request following this format without deviation.

app.py: from flask import Flask, jsonify, request
return jsonify({'message': 'Welcome to the User Management System'}), 200
return jsonify({'message': 'Password reset link has been sent to your email'}), 200
test_app.py: assert resp.get_json() == {'message': 'Welcome to the User Management System'}
assert resp.get_json() == {'message': 'Password reset link has been sent to your email'}

steps: Step 1: Start by setting up the basic structure of the application. This includes creating the main application file (app.py) and setting up a Flask application. Also, create a 'users' dictionary to act as a mock database for storing user information. The keys of this dictionary will be the user's email and the values will be another dictionary containing user details such as password, profile picture, status message, and privacy settings. Write tests to ensure that the Flask application is set up correctly and that the 'users' dictionary is functioning as expected.

Step 2: Implement the user registration and authentication features. This includes creating routes for user sign up and forgotten password recovery. For sign up, the route should accept a POST request with the user's email and password, and add the user to the 'users' dictionary. For password recovery, the route should accept a POST request with the user's email and send a password reset link to the email (for the purpose of this task, just return a message indicating that the link has been sent). Write tests to ensure that these routes are working correctly and that users are being added to the 'users' dictionary.

Step 3: Implement the user profile features. This includes creating routes for setting profile pictures and status messages, and for updating privacy settings. These routes should accept POST requests with the relevant user details and update the 'users' dictionary accordingly. Write tests to ensure that these routes are working correctly and that user details are being updated in the 'users' dictionary.

Step 4: Implement the contact management features. This includes creating routes for blocking/unblocking contacts and for creating, editing, and managing groups. For blocking/unblocking contacts, the routes should accept POST requests with the user's email and the contact's email, and update the 'users' dictionary accordingly. For group management, create a 'groups' dictionary to act as a mock database for storing group information. The keys of this dictionary will be the group name and the values will be a list of user emails. Write tests to ensure that these routes are working correctly and that the 'users' and 'groups' dictionaries are being updated as expected.

Step 5: Implement the messaging features. This includes creating routes for sending and receiving text messages, updating read receipts, encrypting messages, and sharing images. For sending and receiving messages, create a 'messages' dictionary to act as a mock database for storing message information. The keys of this dictionary will be the sender's email and the values will be another dictionary containing the recipient's email and the message details. For read receipts, the message details should include a 'read' status that is updated when a message is received. For encryption, use a simple encryption algorithm to encrypt messages before they are stored in the 'messages' dictionary. For image sharing, allow messages to include an image URL. Write tests to ensure that these routes are working correctly and that the 'messages' dictionary is being updated as expected.

Step 6: Implement the group chat features. This includes creating routes for creating group chats, adding or removing participants, and managing admin roles and permissions. For creating group chats, the route should accept a POST request with the group name, picture, and initial participants, and add the group to the 'groups' dictionary. For adding or removing participants, the routes should accept POST requests with the group name and the participant's email, and update the 'groups' dictionary accordingly. For admin roles and permissions, add an 'admins' list to each group in the 'groups' dictionary and create routes for adding and removing admins. Write tests to ensure that these routes are working correctly and that the 'groups' dictionary is being updated as expected.

Step 7: Implement the status/story feature. This includes creating routes for posting image statuses and for updating status visibility settings. For posting statuses, create a 'statuses' dictionary to act as a mock database for storing status information. The keys of this dictionary will be the user's email and the values will be a list of status details. For status visibility, add a 'visibility' setting to each status that determines who can see the status. Write tests to ensure that these routes are working correctly and that the 'statuses' dictionary is being updated as expected.

Step 8: Implement the web application feature. This includes creating a basic HTML template for the chat application and setting up routes for rendering the template. The template should include sections for displaying user profiles, contacts, groups, messages, and statuses. Write tests to ensure that the template is being rendered correctly and that the routes are working as expected.

Step 9: Implement the connectivity and offline mode features. This includes creating a 'queue' dictionary to act as a mock database for storing messages that are sent when the user is offline. The keys of this dictionary will be the sender's email and the values will be a list of message details. When a user comes online, the messages in their queue should be sent and removed from the queue. Also, add an 'online' status to each user in the 'users' dictionary and create routes for updating this status. Write tests to ensure that these features are working correctly and that the 'queue' and 'users' dictionaries are being updated as expected.

Step 10: Finally, review all the code and tests to ensure that everything is working as expected. Run all the tests and fix any issues that arise. Also, check that all the requirements have been met and that the application provides all the specified features. Once everything is working correctly, the task is complete.
step: Step 3: Implement the user profile features. This includes creating routes for setting profile pictures and status messages, and for updating privacy settings. These routes should accept POST requests with the relevant user details and update the 'users' dictionary accordingly. Write tests to ensure that these routes are working correctly and that user details are being updated in the 'users' dictionary.

Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persist between steps or write operations.

You will get instructions for code to write.
First lay out the names of the core classes, functions, methods that will be necessary, As well as a quick comment on their purpose.
Do not comment on what every file does. Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

You will start with the "entrypoint" file, then go to the ones that are imported by that file, and so on.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

Follow a language and framework appropriate best practice file naming convention.
Make sure that files contain all imports, types etc.  The code should be fully functional. Make sure that code in different files are compatible with each other.
When writing code if you are unsure, write a plausible implementation.
Include module dependency or package manager dependency definition file.

Useful to know:

For Python, you always create an appropriate requirements.txt file.
Always add a comment briefly describing the purpose of the function definition.
Add comments explaining very complex bits of logic.
Always follow the best practices for the requested languages for folder/file structure and how to package the project.
You can use any package and any other packages you wish to install.
You cannot use any databases as none are setup in the local environment, instead mock a database with an in memory dictionary to store data. No data saved to disk will persis between steps or write operations.
When writing a test, make the filename start with the prefix 'test_'.
                                       
Python toolbelt preferences:
- pytest
- dataclasses
- flask

Objective:```
**Global Chat Service (GCS)**

**Overview**:  
A real-time online chat application allowing users to send text messages, images, and create group chats.

**Functional Requirements to implement**:

User Registration and Authentication:
- [ ] 1.1. Sign up using email.
- [ ] 1.2. Forgotten password recovery.

User Profile:
- [ ] 2.1. Allow users to set profile pictures and status messages.
- [ ] 2.2. Privacy settings for who can see user details or last seen status.

Contact Management:
- [ ] 3.1. Block/unblock contacts.
- [ ] 3.2. Create, edit, and manage groups.

Messaging:
- [ ] 4.1. Send and receive real-time text messages.
- [ ] 4.2. Message read receipts (blue ticks or equivalent).
- [ ] 4.3. End-to-end encryption for security.
- [ ] 4.4. Image sharing.
- [ ] 4.5. Emojis, GIFs, and stickers support.

Group Chats:
- [ ] 5.1. Create group chats with a name and picture.
- [ ] 5.2. Add or remove participants.
- [ ] 5.3. Admin roles and permissions.

Status/Story Feature:
- [ ] 6.1. Allow users to post image statuses visible for a limited time.
- [ ] 6.2. Control who can see the status.

Web Application:
- [ ] 7.1. Web-based version accessible from browsers.

Connectivity and Offline Mode:
- [ ] 8.1. Message queuing for when the user is offline; messages are sent once connectivity is restored.
- [ ] 8.2. Display online/offline status.
```

Understand the problem, by creating an extremely detailed step-by-step plan, where each step is long (multiple sentences) and in total includes every single feature requirement specified above, feel free to copy directly from it. Use no more than 10 steps in the plan. Create additional tests, checks and evaluation at each step when applicable to help make an excellent code implementation, where all the code is fully functional. Use best software design practices, and you can output large amounts of code at once. Please include a last sentence to create and run tests when implementing or writing code in that same step. You will receive no human input at any stage, so you cannot use a human to test. Only create a detailed plan to begin with, which includes designing and running tests to check that they all pass. Please be sure to include all of the specified feature requirements in the following plan.
